reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading. 

Imagine your <vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary> (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? They say <reading>nehhhh</reading> (ねえ).
The reading is the on'yomi reading, just like you learned with the kanji.
The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The いち shortens to an いっ and the ほ rendakus to ぽ. One step at a time, right?

The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the ひゃく rendakus to びゃく. This pattern will repeat itself with 三 + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the readings you learned with both kanji. No problemo for a kanji master such as yourself.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

On <vocabulary>both days</vocabulary> of your vacation, you get two boats to <reading>row</reading>! <reading>Gee, two</reading> (りょうじつ) boats at once? Try not to fall in!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

To learn to read this kanji you have to remember the な part of 亡く, though our mnemonic will use the whole thing.

If you're about to become deceased, you are probably <reading>knock</reading>ing (なく) on death's door.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

With the first reading (the more common one), the こん of 今 is actually just こ. This gets shortened sometimes, so look out for it. Also, the 年 is the kun'yomi reading for some reason. It's a total mystery why this is. Perhaps the ancient aliens know, but I do not. You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you.

The second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is こんねん and just follows the jukugo patterns.
You already know how to read this from having learned 仕方, so you should be good to go!
This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You're trying to trace a person back to their origin so you can learn more about them. You finally get there - it's a castle. The problem is that it's surrounded by a huge <reading>moat</reading> (もと) and you can't get past it because the drawbridge is up. Feel the frustration of this. Think about your goal and how close you are to getting to it if it wasn't for this lousy moat.
This uses the kun'yomi of 元 and then it's just kana, so you should know how to read this!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You wanted to remember <vocabulary>everything</vocabulary> about your trip, so you bought every <reading>souve</reading>nir (すべ) available in the entire shop to ensure you had all the mementos possible.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

With your <vocabulary>full effort</vocabulary>, you were able to produce a <reading>Zen</reading> <reading>lock</reading> (ぜんりょく). It's a lock imbued with the power of Zen, meaning no one and nothing could possibly break it. It's the one lock to rule them all.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You know the reading of 日本. Now just add the on'yomi reading of 全 and you should be able to read this word.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the 写る vocab, but here's a refresher just in case:

You have to remember the うつ part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying <reading>うつ</reading>うつうつ over and over again. Say it out loud, too.

The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.

The readings are a bit strange. They're both kun'yomi readings, where 出 is で and 来る is きる. This is different from the reading you originally learned with 来る (くる), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for  the しゅつ, which gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 

Note that the しゅつ from 出 gets shortened to しゅっ. That's a small つ there, not a big one.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Here's a refresher to help you remember the  き portion of this word: 

Something is <vocabulary>snap</vocabulary>ping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a <reading>木</reading> (き) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly <vocabulary>break</vocabulary>s in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

What's in <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's <reading>my</reading> (まえ) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Think about the <vocabulary>south</vocabulary>. What's down there? <reading>Mean Amy</reading> (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this kun'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You turn <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary> a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says <reading>moo</reading> (む).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But! Don't forget, 四 uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death."
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Tell me about your <vocabulary>country</vocabulary>. Now imagine that everyone in your country has <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>knee</reading>s (くに). That's because the national dress code is shorts, so everyone's knees get chilly. That why they have cool knees. You could also imagine cool knees in the sense of trendy knees. What makes for cool knees, in your opinion?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the on'yomi reading, but 土 gets modified to と for some reason. Just remember that the land you're standing on is made of <reading>toe</reading>s... millions of them. Yuck.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Remember how to spot a <vocabulary>foreigner</vocabulary>? That's right, they'll be in <reading>jean</reading>s (じん)!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

It is the <vocabulary>night</vocabulary>, but it is <reading>your</reading> (よる) night.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, 大 uses the kun'yomi reading and 文 is an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

Whenever you see an <vocabulary>uppercase letter</vocabulary>, you shout "<reading>おお</reading>, <reading>Moe</reading>!" (おおも). Your buddy Moe taught you the letters in the first place, so when you get stuck, you yell for him to come help you. And he always does. What a good guy.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 国 is changed to the reading ごく though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Your <vocabulary>younger sister</vocabulary> is really into <reading>emote</reading>s (いもうと). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet,  so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Picture your <vocabulary>older sister</vocabulary> (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. <reading>A ne</reading>cklace (あね). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

"Would you like this item for <vocabulary>cheap</vocabulary>?" 

"<reading>YAASS</reading> (やす), please!"
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading uses the 宝 vocab reading, たから.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. But there's a second reading you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic for both:

What do you do in your <vocabulary>house</vocabulary>? You <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>e</reading>ggs (いえ). You love to eat eggs at <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>. But it has to be on the 内 (うち), a.k.a. the inside, of your house. For some reason you can only eat eggs in the 内 of your house.

Both readings relate to house and home, but いえ is a bit more for the physical building (the house) while うち is more for your personal sense of home, including your family and household.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, 小 uses the kun'yomi reading and 文 is an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

You learned your lowercase letters from <reading>子</reading> <reading>Moe</reading> (こも). That's right, after Moe taught you all the letters, his son 子 Moe taught you the lowercase ones. Such teamwork.
The reading is the on'yomi reading that you learned with the kanji, probably because it normally gets added on to other things, like the names of the state. Examples: カリフォルニア州, ニューヨーク州, etc.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.
The reading for this one is kind of strange. It is the kun'yomi reading for both of the kanji. You know the kun'yomi readings from earlier, back when you learned the vocab 年 and 下.
The reading is the same as 広い, too, so as long as you knew that you knew this reading as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Think of your favorite <vocabulary>shop</vocabulary>. Okay, now imagine yourself going to it. When you arrive, the entire shop is totally <reading>missi</reading>ng (みせ). Feel the shock and awe of this. It's as if it picked up and left overnight. No building, no anything. Just missing.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>After</vocabulary>. Everything happens after. It's a cause and effect chain. One thing happens, and then another thing happens after. This is life. This is the universe. Everything is after. It's an <reading>auto</reading>matic (あと) cycle that just keeps going and going and going.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary> you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? It's うし, which is also the reading for this word.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with this kanji, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case: 

You have to remember the おも part to read this word. To do this, though, you'll have <vocabulary>to think</vocabulary> about that guy... hmm... what was his name? He's on The Simpsons... he's the bartender? I think? <reading>Oh! Moe</reading> (おも) is his name! Thank you. Now I remember.

If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

In your <vocabulary>culture</vocabulary>, everyone drives <reading>bun</reading> <reading>car</reading>s (ぶんか). Indeed, bun cars are the height of culture. And because they're made out of buns, they're much less dangerous.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 早い, you should be able to read this word as well.
Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one <reading>はやくち</reading>.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あか portion. What is あか in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka あか). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>To have</vocabulary> something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "<reading>AAAAHHHH</reading>" (あ).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You see a man walking <vocabulary>east</vocabulary>, toward the sun rising behind that tree, but it's too bright. He trips and <reading>he gash</reading>es (ひがし) his foot on a root that was sticking out of the ground. His foot is torn up really bad, but he tries to take another step and, oh no, he gashes his foot again! This guy is not having an easy time going east.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This is the case here too, but both kanji use their slightly less common secondary readings. You do know both of those, but in case you need a little help, here's a mnemonic anyway:

Be completely <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary>, what's the strangest sound you've ever heard? The <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) going "<reading>jiki</reading> jiki (じき)"?! <vocabulary>Honestly</vocabulary>, that does sound quite strange...

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the ある portion. Imagine yourself going <vocabulary>to walk</vocabulary> outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "<reading>arrrrr</reading>" (ある). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because かつ is being shortened here to かっ. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in つ, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for this word is the same as the reading for the kanji that makes it.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When something starts <vocabulary>to grow</vocabulary> it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "<reading>Ha</reading> (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to learn the <ja>なお</ja> part. Think of it this way. You need <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary> something! It's urgent! You have to fix it <reading>now</reading>! (<ja>なお</ja>).
This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ちょく of 直 is shortened with a small っ, though, so make sure to take note of that.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary> everything there is to know about <reading>sheep</reading> (し). Why? Because you are a busybody who wants to know everything. But for now, you'll settle for sheep. Right now all you know is that sheep are soft, come in many colors, and that they have 360 degree vision with their weird, rectangle eyes. There's even more to know, so you better get on it!
This uses the kun'yomi of 石, which you've already learned, and adds a bit of hiragana, so you should be able to read this!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is わたし. If you don't know that already, just think: "<reading>What, a し</reading>?" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is し.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Both 市立 (municipal) and 私立 (private) are pronounced as しりつ and it's hard to tell them apart when speaking. Although they're not official readings, people sometimes distinguish 市立 and 私立 by pronouncing them as いちりつ and わたくしりつ respectively.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine a <vocabulary>sheep</vocabulary> fighting with Jesus. The first thing it does is <reading>hits Je</reading>sus (ひつじ) in the stomach with its fists, then hits Jesus again with its horns. Try to imagine this playing out, with an announcer calling the shots as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You cut yourself and there's <vocabulary>blood</vocabulary> everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of <reading>chee</reading>se. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.

The reading is also a strange exception. You have to remember the おこな portion. Maybe this mnemonic will help: 

You have <vocabulary>to carry out</vocabulary> a task but don’t know how. “<reading>Oh</reading>, <reading>Cona</reading>n!” (おこな) you shout. You always shout “Oh, Conan!” when you have to carry out something tough, because it summons the spirit of Detective Conan. He’s a genius, so his spirit can help you with anything at all. Even your WaniKani reviews. Go ahead and try it now. Shout “Oh, Conan!” Did you do it? Good. Now carry out those reviews!
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same as 足りる, so if you know that you can add things up to this.
The reading is the same as 足りる (たりる) which you should have seen in Level 4.

This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of 足 from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of 首 from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have something that's really long. It's this crazy hair growing out of the tip of your nose. You don't really care either way if it stays or goes, but you're too lazy to cut it off. Your parents, though, keep trying to <reading>nag</reading> (なが) you to trim it. Imagine this process happening and be irritated about it. What naggers.

You have to remember the た portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself <vocabulary>eat</vocabulary>ing some <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).
You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.
This word contains the reading you learned with the kanji. Everything else is hiragana.
